principle: Your total daily energy expenditure (TDEE) is the total number of calories your body burns in a day to function and stay alive and its split into basal metabolic rate (BMR, around 70%), non-exercise activity thermogenesis (NEAT), thermic effect of food (TEF), and exercise activity thermogenesis (EAT).

Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR): this is the largest chunk, accounting for around 70% of your TDEE. It's the number of calories your body burns at rest to perform essential functions like breathing, circulation, and cell repair.

Non-Exercise Activity Thermogenesis (NEAT): this covers calories burned through all your daily movements that aren't planned exercise. Think fidgeting, walking around, standing, and even things like typing. NEAT can make up about 25% of your TDEE.
Thermic Effect of Food (TEF): this is the energy your body uses to digest, absorb, and store the food you eat. It's about 10% of your TDEE.

Exercise Activity Thermogenesis (EAT): this is the least significant contributor, at around 5% of TDEE. It refers to the calories you burn specifically through planned exercise sessions like running, weightlifting, or cycling.

Circadian cycle regulation: expose body to sunlight in the morning, at least artificial light, avoid eating at least 1 hour after waking up, ideally until noon, avoid eating at least 2/3 hours before sleep, minimize (artificial) light exposure in the last third of the day, aim to exercise during the morning, use the first third of the day for more routine/less engaging activities, and the second third for more cognitive activities.

Shorter inhale, longer exhale = calmer state, heart shrinks ever so slightly, heartbeat slows down to compensate blood movement, blood moves faster through the heart; Longer inhale, shorter exhale = more energetic state, heart enlarges, heartbeat has to speed up to compensate blood movement, blood moves slower through the heart.
Going to sleep feeling hungry is a good indicator of a caloric deficit.

Mental toughness: tolerance, fortitude, resilience, adaptability.
Tolerance: how long it takes before you falter from a negative experience.
Fortitude: how low you falter for from a negative experience.
Resilience: how long it takes to recover from a negative experience.
Adaptability: your new baseline fortitude after recovery from a bad experience, which can be lower, match, or higher than the previous baseline.

If you don't know what to write next, use a pain point, example, personal story, anecdote, statistic, metaphor, quote, advice, what, how, why.

At your funeral, friends and family will argue over who gets your belongings. People will talk about the food and the venue. Your life will be summarized in 2-3 paragraphs. Conversations will shift from your life to their lives. Your friends will drive away thinking about what's next on their to-do list. Some people won't be able to make it because "something came up." And most of the people you know today won't even be there. You're gonna die. People will move on (in weeks not years). Do what you want.

Prepare the night before.
Say no to opportunities that don't bring value to your life.
Follow up quickly.
Follow up multiple times.
Deliver value at every interaction with the other person.
Never make the same mistake twice.

First change how you view yourself when you want to change.

Aim for full of range of motion on all reps.
Aim for 3 or less reps in reserve per set.
Generally speaking strength training uses sets of up to 6 reps whereas hypertrophy uses up to 30 reps.
Eat 1 to 1.3g of protein per kg of target of body weight daily.
When you think you're done you still have 40% left in the tank.
A deeper stretch emphasises muscle growth.
Control the eccentric (stretching) phase of the lift. A slower tempo can increase time under tension and enhance the stretch stimulus.
Perform exercises with good technique and controlled eccentric to minimise the risk of injury.
Grow enough muscle mass so you can at least tell apart different muscle groups in the nude.
